entries.description: The present simple tense is used to describe habitual actions, general truths, and scheduled events in the present
examples: I walk to school every day
The sun rises in the east
exceptions: Third person singular adds -s: He walks
Verbs ending in -y change to -ies: He studies

entries.description: The past simple tense is used to describe completed actions in the past at a specific time
exceptions: Irregular verbs have unique past forms: go -> went

entries.description: Most nouns form plurals by adding -s or -es to the singular form
exceptions: Nouns ending in -y preceded by consonant change -y to -ies
Some nouns have irregular plural forms

entries.description: The verb must agree with the subject in number and person
exceptions: Collective nouns can take singular or plural verbs
Some subjects appear plural but take singular verbs

entries.description: Comparative adjectives are used to compare two things
examples: This book is longer than that one
She is more intelligent than her brother
